chapter.title: 1 Here Comes Charlie
chapter.summary_local: The chapter introduces Charlie Bucket and his extended family — his parents and four grandparents — who live cramped in a tiny, cold house because they are very poor. Mr Bucket works screwing toothpaste caps but cannot earn enough; meals are meagre and Sunday is the only slightly better day. Charlie longs for chocolate, treasures a single small birthday bar by nibbling it over many days, and must walk past the enormous, famous Wonka’s Chocolate Factory each day, which torments him with its rich smells and mystery.

chapter.title: 2 Mr Willy Wonka's Factory
chapter.summary_local: Each evening Charlie visits his four very elderly grandparents; their faces brighten when he arrives and they tell stories together, briefly easing the family’s hunger and poverty. Charlie asks about Mr Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory, and an excited Grandpa Joe recounts Wonka’s worldwide fame and astonishing inventions—never-melting chocolate ice cream, marshmallows tasting of violets, colour-changing caramels, eternal chewing-gum, sugar balloons, and magical bird’s-egg sweets—while the other grandparents and Charlie’s parents listen. Grandpa Joe then begins the tale of Prince Pondicherry.

The factory was closed and Wonka vanished, but months later it mysteriously resumed production while the gates remained locked and faint shadows of very small people were seen behind the windows. The town is baffled as sweets continue to be sent out by Post Office trucks. The chapter ends with Mr. Bucket bringing a newspaper announcing that the Wonka factory will at last be opened to a lucky few.

chapter.title: 10 The Family Begins to Starve

The toothpaste factory where Mr Bucket worked closes, leaving him unemployed; food rations shrink until the whole family begins to starve. Charlie grows pale and weak, conserving energy by moving slowly and skipping play. Each day he breathes the delicious smell from Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory. One afternoon, desperately hungry, he finds a fifty-pence piece in the gutter and decides to buy a bar of chocolate and bring the rest home to his mother.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Lies huddled in bed with the other elders; notices Charlie's emaciation and urges that the child must be fed, dismissing the elders' own needs.

relationships.justification: Grandfather who advocates prioritizing Charlie's nourishment over the elders'.

characters.name: Grandma Josephine
characters.character_actions: Huddles with the other elders against the cold and expresses misery about their inability to help Charlie.

relationships.justification: Grandmother who is distressed by the family's poverty and Charlie's hunger.

characters.name: Grandpa George
characters.character_actions: Lies with the other elders to keep warm and praises Charlie, saying he deserves better than their current conditions.

relationships.justification: Grandfather who defends Charlie and laments the child's poor condition.

characters.name: Mr Willy Wonka
characters.character_actions: Not present in person; his giant chocolate factory emits tempting smells of melting chocolate that daily attract Charlie.

relationships.justification: Factory is a source of temptation for Charlie; no direct interaction occurs in this chapter.

chapter.title: 11 The Miracle
chapter.summary_local: Charlie buys a second Whipple-Scrumptious Fudge-mallow Delight and discovers the final Golden Ticket inside. The shopkeeper announces the find, drawing a crowd that offers money and pressures Charlie. The shopkeeper protects and advises him to run home immediately. Overwhelmed with joy, Charlie runs past Willy Wonka’s factory, waves, and arrives at home clutching the Golden Ticket.

characters.name: Charlie
characters.character_actions: Buys two chocolate bars, devours the first, finds the Golden Ticket in the second, stands stunned as a crowd forms, resists offers to sell, accepts the shopkeeper's advice to run home, waves at Wonka's factory and arrives home holding the ticket.

relationships.justification: Shopkeeper protects Charlie from the crowd and urges him to take the ticket straight home.
The tall man tries to buy the Golden Ticket from Charlie offering money and a bicycle.
The woman loudly offers a higher sum for the ticket and pressures Charlie to sell.
The large boy expresses anger and envy, complaining he has bought many bars without finding a ticket.
The girl mocks Charlie, calling him names and laughing at his slenderness and luck.

characters.name: Shopkeeper
characters.character_actions: Sells Charlie the chocolate bars, reacts with ecstatic surprise at the Golden Ticket, shouts to draw a crowd, rebukes those pressuring Charlie, takes Charlie by the arm and urges him to run home with the ticket.

relationships.justification: He protects and guides Charlie, telling him to take the ticket home immediately.

characters.name: Tall man
characters.character_actions: Leans over Charlie and whispers an offer to buy the Golden Ticket for fifty pounds and a new bicycle.

relationships.justification: Attempts to acquire Charlie's Golden Ticket by offering money and goods.

characters.name: Woman
characters.character_actions: Shouts a louder offer—two hundred pounds—for the Golden Ticket and encourages Charlie to sell it.

relationships.justification: Pressures Charlie with a high monetary offer to give up the ticket.

characters.name: Large boy
characters.character_actions: Complains angrily about not finding a Golden Ticket despite buying many bars, showing jealousy.

relationships.justification: Expresses envy and resentment toward Charlie for finding the ticket.

characters.name: Girl
characters.character_actions: Laughs at Charlie and derides him as a 'skinny little shrimp' while others crowd around.

relationships.justification: Mocks and belittles Charlie in front of the crowd, showing contempt and jealousy.

chapter.title: 12 What It Said on the Golden Ticket
chapter.summary_local: Charlie finds the fifth Golden Ticket, rushes home and reveals it to his astonished family. Grandpa Joe erupts in joyful celebration, leaps out of bed and volunteers to accompany Charlie. Mr Bucket reads Willy Wonka’s invitation aloud: the factory visit is tomorrow at ten, with one or two family members allowed and lifetime food supplies promised. Reporters then swarm the house, creating pandemonium until late at night.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
aliases: finder of the fifth Golden Ticket
characters.character_actions: Finds the fifth Golden Ticket in a chocolate bar, rushes home shouting, shows the ticket to his family, listens as Mr Bucket reads Wonka's invitation, prepares (with family) for the visit, and endures reporters swarming the house.

relationships.justification: Grandson; Grandpa Joe celebrates wildly and offers to accompany Charlie to the factory.
Mother; she cares for the household and decides who can accompany Charlie.
Father; he reads the Golden Ticket aloud and manages the reporters.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Initially skeptical, then erupts into ecstatic celebration, leaps out of bed despite years of infirmity, dances, volunteers eagerly to accompany Charlie to Wonka's factory.

relationships.justification: Grandfather; he expresses joy and insists on going with Charlie as his keeper.
Spouse; they share the bedside and are involved in the household scene together.
Daughter-in-law; they coordinate who should accompany Charlie and discuss care for the other grandparents.

characters.name: Mrs Bucket
characters.character_actions: Serving soup to the grandparents when Charlie arrives, stays composed, rules out leaving three grandparents alone so cannot accompany Charlie, helps decide who should go, laughs at Grandpa Joe's excitement.

relationships.justification: Mother; she cares for Charlie and helps prepare the household for the visit.
Spouse; they consult about who should accompany Charlie.
Daughter-in-law; she comments on his sudden vigor and supports his going.

characters.name: Mr Bucket
characters.character_actions: Returns home cold and tired, is told about the Golden Ticket, reads Willy Wonka’s invitation aloud with trembling hands, modestly declines to insist on going, and later deals with and finally sends away the reporters.

relationships.justification: Father; he reads the ticket to the family and helps manage the ensuing publicity.
Spouse; they discuss who should accompany Charlie and share household responsibilities.
They invade the house seeking the story and create pandemonium that he must control.

characters.name: Grandma Josephine
characters.character_actions: Is serving soup in bed, freezes in shock when Charlie reveals the ticket, has soup accidentally flung into her face when Grandpa Joe leaps up and celebrates.

relationships.justification: Spouse; she shares the bedside and is the recipient of his celebratory mishap.
Daughter-in-law; Mrs Bucket cares for her and the other elders.

characters.name: Other Grandparents
characters.character_actions: Present in bed eating soup, drop their spoons and freeze in stunned silence upon seeing the Golden Ticket; are considered when deciding who may accompany Charlie.

relationships.justification: Relatives; they are members of Charlie's household affected by the discovery.
Caretaker; she refuses to leave them alone, influencing who can go with Charlie.

characters.name: Newspapermen and Photographers
characters.character_actions: Track down the finder of the fifth Golden Ticket, swarm the Bucket house asking questions and taking photographs, cause pandemonium that lasts for hours until nearly midnight.

relationships.justification: They pursue Charlie for the story, seeking interviews and photos.
They pressure the family; Mr Bucket deals with and eventually removes them from the house.

characters.name: Willy Wonka
characters.character_actions: Is present only through the printed Golden Ticket: invites winners to visit his factory on the first of February, promises surprises and lifetime food supplies, and sets the rules for the visit.

relationships.justification: Author of the invitation; he is the host who has invited Charlie to the factory.

chapter.title: 13 The Big Day Arrives
chapter.summary_local: On a bright, snowy morning the five Golden Ticket children and their grown-ups gather outside Wonka’s factory amid a noisy, pushing crowd. Parents hold the excited children back as onlookers shout identifying comments — mocking Violet’s gum, pointing out Augustus, Mike Teavee and Veruca Salt, and noticing thin Charlie Bucket standing beside Grandpa Joe without a coat. The police shield the group until, at ten o’clock, the factory gates creak open and someone appears, prompting a collective exclamation from the crowd.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
characters.character_actions: Stands beside Grandpa Joe at the factory gates, holds Joe's hand, listens to the crowd's remarks about the other children, is pointed out by onlookers and noted for wearing no coat in the cold.

relationships.justification: Grandpa Joe stands beside Charlie, holding his hand and accompanying him to the factory.
Charlie is one of the five children shielded together by police and waiting to enter the factory.
Onlookers point him out and comment on his thinness and lack of a coat.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Stands quietly beside Charlie, holds Charlie's hand and smiles when Charlie squeezes it; acts as Charlie's companion as they wait at the gates.

relationships.justification: He accompanies Charlie closely, holding his hand and providing support at the event.

characters.name: Violet Beauregarde
characters.character_actions: Stands among the ticket-holders still chewing the same piece of gum; the crowd remarks on her constant gum-chewing and watches her eagerly.

relationships.justification: Her parents are present and hold her back to prevent climbing over the gates.
Spectators loudly identify and comment on her gum-chewing and appearance.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Stands at the gates with his parents; the crowd points him out and comments on his enormous size and appetite.

relationships.justification: His parents restrain him and accompany him to the factory entrance.
Onlookers identify him by his size and make remarks about him.

characters.name: Mike Teavee
characters.character_actions: Stands among the famous children wearing a Lone Ranger motif windcheater and toy pistols; the crowd labels him a television fiend and comments on his appearance.

relationships.justification: His parents are present and help restrain him from crowd or gate-climbing.
Spectators recognize him and remark on his television obsession and toy pistols.

characters.name: Veruca Salt
characters.character_actions: Stands in a silver mink coat with her parents nearby; the crowd singles her out as the spoiled girl whose father bought many bars to find a ticket.

relationships.justification: Her father and mother accompany her; the crowd describes her as the girl who gets anything she wants from her father.
Onlookers discuss her reputation as spoiled and point her out among the children.

characters.name: Crowd
characters.character_actions: Gathers outside the gates, pushes and shouts, identifies and comments on each of the five ticket-holders, and falls silent as the factory gates begin to open.

relationships.justification: They have gathered specifically to see and shout about the famous children arriving at the factory.
Police form a barrier to hold the crowd back from the gates.

chapter.title: 14 Mr Willy Wonka
chapter.summary_local: Mr Willy Wonka greets the five Golden Ticket winners and their parents at the factory gates, delighting in each child as he exuberantly ushers them inside. He inspects the tickets, warmly welcomes Augustus Gloop, Veruca Salt, Violet Beauregarde, Mike Teavee, and Charlie Bucket (with Grandpa Joe), then leads the group into a vast, warm corridor filled with delicious smells. The party weaves through a maze of sloping passages underground as Wonka chatters about the factory’s enormous secret rooms, finally stopping before a door labeled THE CHOCOLATE ROOM.

characters.name: Mr Willy Wonka
characters.character_actions: Appears at the factory gates in flamboyant dress, greets and enthusiastically welcomes each Golden Ticket winner and their parents, inspects tickets, leads the group through the factory corridors while chattering about the underground rooms, and stops before the Chocolate Room door.

relationships.justification: Greets Charlie warmly, recognizes his recent ticket, and acts as host and guide for him and the other visitors.
Seizes Augustus's hand energetically and personally welcomes him into the factory.
Addresses Veruca and her parents by name and warmly admits them after inspecting the ticket.
Meets and greets Charlie's grandfather politely when Charlie is introduced.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
characters.character_actions: Steps forward to present his Golden Ticket with Grandpa Joe, watches the gates close behind him, follows Mr Wonka into the factory, notices the warm corridor and delicious smells, and holds Grandpa Joe's hand while they proceed.

relationships.justification: Is accompanied by and holds the hand of his grandfather throughout the tour.
Is greeted and guided by Wonka as one of the ticket winners entering the factory.
One of the five children touring the factory together.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Accompanies Charlie, sniffs appreciatively at the delightful smells in the corridor, cautions Charlie to hold his hand, and greets Mr Wonka when introduced.

relationships.justification: Grandfather to Charlie and accompanies him on the tour, physically guiding him.
Is greeted and addressed warmly by Wonka upon presentation of Charlie's ticket.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Steps forward first to announce himself and have his ticket checked; is enthusiastically greeted by Mr Wonka and admitted into the factory with his parents.

relationships.justification: Wonka seizes his hand and personally welcomes him into the factory.
Is accompanied to the gates and admitted into the factory with his parents present.

characters.name: Veruca Salt
characters.character_actions: Presents her ticket and is greeted by Wonka, who comments on her name and attire; her father and mother are acknowledged as present and she is admitted.

relationships.justification: Her father is present at the gate and is addressed by Wonka when admitting Veruca.
Her mother is acknowledged by Wonka as present at the gate.
Wonka greets Veruca and her parents warmly and admits them after checking the ticket.

characters.name: Violet Beauregarde
characters.character_actions: Comes forward to have her ticket examined and is warmly greeted by Wonka, then follows the group into the factory.

relationships.justification: Has her ticket inspected and receives an energetic welcome from Wonka before entering.
Both are among the five children admitted and tour the factory together.

characters.name: Mike Teavee
characters.character_actions: Presents his ticket, receives Wonka's enthusiastic greeting along with the other children, and follows the tour into the factory.

relationships.justification: Has his ticket checked and is warmly received by Wonka at the gate.
One of the five children touring the factory together.

characters.name: Mr Salt
characters.character_actions: Is present at the gate as Veruca Salt's father and is greeted by Wonka when Veruca's ticket is checked.

relationships.justification: Identified as Veruca's father present at the entrance during admission.
Is addressed and greeted by Wonka when Veruca and her parents arrive.

characters.name: Mrs Salt
characters.character_actions: Is present at the gate as Veruca Salt's mother and is greeted by Wonka along with the rest of the family.

relationships.justification: Present as Veruca's mother at the factory gates.
Mentioned and greeted by Wonka during the admission of the Salt family.

chapter.title: 15 The Chocolate Room
chapter.summary_local: Mr Wonka unlocks the Chocolate Room and reveals a valley with a hot, brown chocolate river, a towering waterfall and glass pipes that suck up the chocolate. The banks are planted with edible trees, flowers and swudge (minty sugar) grass. The children taste the confectionery plants — Augustus greedily grabs a handful — and Veruca excitedly spots several tiny, long-haired people below the waterfall. The little figures laugh and point; Mr Wonka identifies them as Oompa-Loompas.

characters.name: Mr Wonka
characters.character_actions: Unlocks and opens the door to the Chocolate Room, explains its machinery (waterfall, glass pipes) and edible landscaping, invites the children to taste swudge grass and buttercups, points out the chocolate river and the Oompa-Loompas below the waterfall.

relationships.justification: Guides Charlie and the other children on the factory tour and explains the factory's workings to them.
Introduces them as the little people working in his factory and appears familiar with them.
Addresses and guides Grandpa Joe among the visitors while presenting the Chocolate Room.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
characters.character_actions: Watches in awe as Wonka reveals the Chocolate Room, tastes a blade of swudge grass, points out the tiny figures across the river and asks Grandpa Joe if he can see them.

relationships.justification: Grandpa Joe is Charlie's grandfather and speaks with him throughout the visit, sharing excitement.
Followed and listened to Wonka's explanations during the factory tour.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Expresses delight at the edible landscape, declares he could eat the whole field, eagerly scans the riverbank and recognizes the tiny figures Charlie and others spot.

relationships.justification: Grandpa Joe is Charlie's grandfather and shares the visit with him, encouraging his excitement.
Listens to Wonka's explanations and reacts appreciatively during the tour.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Ignores tasting a single blade and instead scoops up a large handful of swudge grass, demonstrating gluttony and eagerness to consume the edible landscape.

relationships.justification: Competes informally for treats by grabbing a big handful, drawing attention from the group.

characters.name: Violet Beauregarde
characters.character_actions: Removes her world-record chewing-gum from her mouth and carefully places it behind her ear before sampling the edible plants.

relationships.justification: Part of the visiting children; her gum habit and competitive nature mark her interactions with peers.

characters.name: Veruca Salt
characters.character_actions: Screams and points frantically across the river upon spotting the tiny figures below the waterfall, drawing everyone's attention and excitement.

relationships.justification: Acts loudly and demands attention, creating a scene among the other children during the tour.

characters.name: Oompa-Loompas
characters.character_actions: Seen below the waterfall as tiny, long-haired people no larger than dolls; they stop work, point at the visitors, whisper among themselves and burst into laughter.

relationships.justification: Presented by Wonka as the small people associated with his factory; they appear to work in his operations.
React to the visitors with curiosity and laughter; their exact status and motives are not yet explained in this chapter.

chapter.title: 16 The Oompa-Loompas
chapter.summary_local: Mr Wonka introduces the Oompa-Loompas to his visitors, recounting how he found them in Loompaland, their miserable diet of green caterpillars, and how he persuaded their leader to move to his factory by promising unlimited cacao and chocolate. He describes their tastes, clothes, love of music, and mischievousness. Veruca Salt demands an Oompa-Loompa from her father, who promises to get her one. Meanwhile Augustus Gloop scoops hot chocolate from the riverbank; Mrs Gloop warns him to stop.

characters.name: Mr Wonka
characters.character_actions: Presents and narrates the backstory of the Oompa-Loompas: their jungle life, craving for cacao, and how he recruited and smuggled the tribe to work in his factory, promising them cacao and chocolate.

relationships.justification: He rescued/recruited them to work in his factory and supplies them with cacao and chocolate.
She challenges the existence of Loompaland while he is addressing the visitors.

characters.name: Oompa-Loompas
characters.character_actions: Described as small jungle people imported from Loompaland; love cacao, sing, dance, are mischievous, wear jungle clothes, and now work in Wonka's factory across the river.

relationships.justification: They live and work in his factory after he offered them unlimited cacao and chocolate.
The leader negotiated the tribe's departure from Loompaland and led them to Wonka's factory.

characters.name: Oompa-Loompa leader
characters.character_actions: Recalled in Wonka's story as the thin, hungry leader who accepted Wonka's offer (throwing away his bowl of mashed caterpillars) and led his people to be smuggled to the factory.

relationships.justification: He is the head of the tribe who decided their move to Wonka's factory.
He agreed to Wonka's offer to provide cacao and chocolate in exchange for relocating his tribe.

characters.name: Veruca Salt
characters.character_actions: Interrupts Wonka's talk, loudly demands an Oompa-Loompa from her father immediately and insists on taking one home.

relationships.justification: She is his daughter and directly orders him to obtain an Oompa-Loompa for her.

characters.name: Mr Salt
characters.character_actions: Interrupts slightly to calm Veruca; responds to her demand by promising to get her an Oompa-Loompa before the day is out.

relationships.justification: He is Veruca's father and promises to fulfill her demand.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Sneaks to the riverbank and kneels scooping up and greedily eating hot melted chocolate directly from the river.

relationships.justification: She addresses him as her child and warns him about his behavior at the riverbank.

characters.name: Mrs Gloop
characters.character_actions: Notices Augustus at the riverbank and admonishes him, expressing concern about his grabbing chocolate.

relationships.justification: She scolds him as her son and tries to restrain his greedy behavior.

characters.name: Mrs Salt
characters.character_actions: Skeptically claims Loompaland does not exist and interrupts Wonka; identified as a geography teacher challenging his statement.

relationships.justification: She disputes his account of Loompaland while he is speaking to the visitors.

chapter.title: 17 Augustus Gloop Goes up the Pipe
chapter.summary_local: Augustus Gloop ignores warnings and laps from the chocolate river, falls in, and is sucked up into a glass pipe that carries him toward the Fudge Room. He becomes stuck, then is shot along the pipe out of sight. His parents panic; Mr Wonka reassures them, summons an Oompa-Loompa to escort the Gloops to the Fudge Room, and jokes about Augustus’s fate. As the Gloops depart, a group of Oompa-Loompas sing a mocking moralizing song about Augustus’s greed while Mr Wonka insists the verses are nonsense and the child will be unharmed.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Ignores warnings, laps from the chocolate river, falls in and is sucked into a glass pipe; becomes stuck briefly and is then propelled through the pipe toward the Fudge Room, out of sight.

relationships.justification: Mrs Gloop repeatedly calls and panics for her son throughout the chapter.
Mr Gloop is Augustus’s father and accompanies Mrs Gloop, preparing to help him.
Augustus is a factory visitor whose actions Mr Wonka admonishes and then explains about.
Oompa-Loompas are sent to search for Augustus and later sing about him.

characters.name: Mr Wonka
characters.character_actions: Attempts to stop Augustus from drinking the chocolate, reassures the panicking Gloops, clicks to summon an Oompa-Loompa to escort them to the Fudge Room, and makes darkly humorous remarks about Augustus’s possible fate while insisting the boy will be safe.

relationships.justification: He gives orders to the Oompa-Loompas and they respond immediately to his clicks.
Factory owner interacting with a visiting child who breaks rules and is then taken away by factory systems.
Host interacting with the boy’s parents as they demand answers and assistance.

characters.name: Mrs Gloop
characters.character_actions: Shouts at Augustus to stop, panics and screams that he will drown or be turned into fudge, waves her umbrella and demands Mr Wonka lead her to her son; rushes off toward the Fudge Room escorted by an Oompa-Loompa.

relationships.justification: She is Augustus’s mother and reacts hysterically when he is pulled into the pipe.
She and Mr Gloop are together as Augustus’s parents; they argue and act as a unit.

characters.name: Mr Gloop
characters.character_actions: Calls to Augustus, grumbles about diving into the chocolate because of his best suit, prepares to remove his jacket to help, shows indignation at Wonka’s remarks, and accompanies his wife and the Oompa-Loompa to the Fudge Room.

relationships.justification: He is Augustus’s father and is present during the accident and aftermath.
He and Mrs Gloop act together trying to rescue their son.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
characters.character_actions: Observes Augustus being sucked into the pipe, notices when Augustus slows and becomes stuck, comments with Grandpa Joe about the situation, and listens as the Oompa-Loompas begin their song.

relationships.justification: Grandpa Joe speaks with Charlie, guiding his reactions during the incident.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Whispers to Charlie, remarks about Augustus slowing and sticking in the pipe, calms Charlie about the Oompa-Loompas’ singing and hopes their verses are only jokes.

relationships.justification: Grandpa Joe is Charlie’s grandfather and speaks comfortingly to him.

characters.name: Oompa-Loompa (escort)
characters.character_actions: Appears immediately when Mr Wonka clicks, bows, laughs at Mrs Gloop, and escorts Mr and Mrs Gloop to the Fudge Room to search for Augustus with instructions to poke around the chocolate-mixing barrel.

relationships.justification: Responds to Wonka’s summons and follows his instructions to find Augustus.
Acts as their guide/escort to the Fudge Room at Wonka’s command.

characters.name: Oompa-Loompas (singers)
characters.character_actions: On the far side of the river they beat small drums, chant and then sing a long moralizing song about Augustus’s greed while the visitors listen; their verses mock Augustus and describe how greed is dealt with.

relationships.justification: They sing about Augustus’s behavior, mocking and moralizing about his greed.
They perform within the factory under Wonka’s direction and he dismisses their words as nonsense.

chapter.title: 18 Down the Chocolate River
chapter.summary_local: Mr. Willy Wonka ushers the group into a sparkling pink boiled‑sweet boat rowed by scores of Oompa‑Loompas for a swift trip down the chocolate river. Charlie and Grandpa Joe drink warm river chocolate and revel. The boat rockets into a dark white tunnel, lights are switched on, and passengers glimpse labelled storeroom doors as Wonka jokes and urges the rowers. Parents complain that Wonka is mad; Wonka remains jubilant and suddenly orders the boat stopped as a bright red door appears.

characters.name: Willy Wonka
characters.character_actions: Leads everyone to his pink boiled‑sweet yacht, commands the Oompa‑Loompas to row, gives Charlie and Grandpa Joe mugs of chocolate, switches tunnel lights on, urges speed, banters with the children and parents, and suddenly orders the boat stopped at sight of a red door.

relationships.justification: Gives Charlie a mug of chocolate, speaks kindly and pays attention to him during the tour.
Offers Grandpa Joe chocolate, jokes with him, and they sit together in the boat.
Directs and commands the Oompa‑Loompas who row his boat and follow his orders.
The parents loudly call him crazy and question his behavior during the tour.
Answers and teases Violet's questions while continuing the tour.
Listens to Veruca's demands and brushes them off, keeping control of the excursion.
Warns Mike not to lick the boat and interacts briefly with him.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
characters.character_actions: Sits beside Grandpa Joe in the boat, holds his hand, drinks a mug of river chocolate and experiences intense pleasure and wonder, points out a storeroom door while watching the tunnel.

relationships.justification: Sits beside and holds Grandpa Joe's hand; Grandpa Joe guides and comforts him.
Receives chocolate and attention from Wonka and follows his tour.

characters.name: Grandpa Joe
characters.character_actions: Sits behind Charlie, whispers wry remarks, drinks chocolate from the river, encourages Charlie's excitement, and defends Wonka when other parents criticize him.

relationships.justification: Grandfather to Charlie; comforts and shares the experience with him.
Accepts Wonka's hospitality, praises the chocolate, and defends him to the other parents.

characters.name: Oompa-Loompas
characters.character_actions: Man dozens of oars (many Oompa‑Loompas to each oar), row the pink boat rapidly, laugh and shriek collectively, and obey Wonka's commands (including speeding and reacting when lights are switched on).

relationships.justification: Follow Wonka's instructions to row, laugh together, and run the boat as his staff.
Provide rowing service for the visitors and interact minimally with them.

characters.name: Violet Beauregarde
characters.character_actions: Asks why the Oompa‑Loompas are laughing, screams in the darkness as the boat enters the tunnel, and makes remarks about storeroom labels (beans).

relationships.justification: Interacts with Wonka during the tour and asks him questions.
Travels with the other golden‑ticket children and exchanges reactions with them.

characters.name: Veruca Salt
characters.character_actions: Demands a pink boat like Wonka's from her father, asks about whips she sees on a storeroom door, and behaves with entitled impatience.

relationships.justification: Constantly makes demands to her father (present in prior context) and expects him to buy things for her.
Addresses Wonka and asks questions during the tour; Wonka brushes off her demands.

characters.name: Mike Teavee
characters.character_actions: Is warned by Wonka not to lick the boat, asks about 'hair cream' when he sees it on a storeroom door, and otherwise remains one of the observing children.

relationships.justification: Interacts briefly when Wonka admonishes him about licking the boat and answers questions.
Travels with the other golden‑ticket children and reacts to the ride alongside them.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Mentioned by Wonka as having fallen (implied from earlier events); not present in the boat and said to 'come out in the wash.'

relationships.justification: Wonka references Augustus's disappearance and reassures others he will reappear.

characters.name: Other parents
characters.character_actions: Express collective alarm and disapproval of Wonka's behavior, shouting that he is crazy, balmy, and other insults during the wild boat ride.

relationships.justification: They loudly criticize and distrust Wonka's conduct during the tour and the tunnel ride.
Accompany their children on the tour and react to events on their behalf.

chapter.title: 19 The Inventing Room – Everlasting Gobstoppers and Hair Toffee
chapter.summary_local: Mr Wonka leads the group into his most secret workshop, the Inventing Room, after the Oompa-Loompas stop the boat and unlock the door. He forbids touching anything and gleefully shows off bubbling pots, strange machines and two inventions: Everlasting Gobstoppers (candies that never shrink) and Hair Toffee (which makes hair grow uncontrollably). The children react—Violet likens the Gobstoppers to gum, Mike objects to a remark about bald children, and Veruca scoffs at the idea of a beard—while Wonka enthuses and mentions an Oompa-Loompa currently testing a Gobstopper in the next room.

characters.name: Mr Wonka
characters.character_actions: Stops the boat, unlocks the Inventing Room, warns everyone not to touch, excitedly tours the machinery and pots, demonstrates Everlasting Gobstoppers and Hair Toffee, recounts testing anecdotes including an Oompa-Loompa tester.

relationships.justification: He gives orders, the Oompa-Loompas row the boat and operate machines under his direction.
He leads Charlie into the Inventing Room and shows him the inventions, addressing the group.
He explains the inventions to them, instructs them not to touch, and answers their reactions.

characters.name: Charlie Bucket
characters.character_actions: Scrambles into the Inventing Room with the others, stares in awe at the bubbling pots and machines, stands on his toes to peer into the Hair Toffee saucepan and listens to Wonka's explanations.

relationships.justification: Follows Wonka into the room and watches him demonstrate inventions.
Present together on the factory tour, reacting to the inventions as fellow visitors.

characters.name: Augustus Gloop
characters.character_actions: Enters the room with the group and joins the other children in promising not to touch anything; listens to Wonka's demonstrations.

relationships.justification: Tours the Inventing Room alongside the other children as fellow visitors.
Receives Wonka's instructions and explanations during the tour.

characters.name: Violet Beauregarde

Wonka shows the gum to Violet and reacts to her recognition with praise and a back slap.

chapter.title: 21 Good-bye Violet
chapter.summary_local: Mr. Wonka unveils an experimental three-course chewing-gum. Violet Beauregarde ignores his warnings, grabs and chews the gum, experiences soup, roast beef and blueberry pie — then her skin and hair turn deep blue and she rapidly swells into a giant blueberry. Mr. Wonka orders Oompa-Loompas to roll her to the boat and take her to the Juicing Room to be squeezed and repaired. As she is taken away, the Oompa-Loompas sing a long cautionary song condemning persistent gum-chewing and warning about Violet’s fate.

Guest/visitor relationship during the factory tour; interacts about Violet’s condition.

relationships.justification: Fellow tour participant and competitor; present among the other children during the demonstration.

chapter.title: 22 Along the Corridor
chapter.summary_local: Mr Willy Wonka hustles the remaining group — Charlie Bucket, Grandpa Joe, Veruca Salt, Mike Teavee and several grown-ups — down a maze of pink corridors past many doors labeled with whimsical inventions. chapter.title: 23 Square Sweets That Look Round
chapter.summary_local: The group stops at a room containing rows of small white square sweets with painted pink faces. Mr Wonka insists they are "square sweets that look round"; when he opens the door the tiny faces turn to look at the visitors, proving his point. Oompa-Loompas are painting more faces. Past another door labeled "BUTTERSCOTCH AND BUTTERGIN" the Oompa-Loompas are heard celebrating. Wonka hurriedly leads the party on through corridors and down a long flight of stairs, sliding down the banister while Mrs Salt and Mrs Teavee struggle to keep up.

characters.name: Mr Wonka
characters.character_actions: Displays the square sweets, argues playfully about their appearance, opens the door to make the faces look round, describes Oompa-Loompas' taste for butterscotch, leads the group rapidly through corridors and slides down the banister.

chapter.summary_local: The group views Mr. Wonka’s Nut Room, where a hundred specially trained squirrels crack and sort walnuts. Veruca Salt demands a squirrel, rushes inside despite warnings, and is seized by the squirrels, judged a “bad nut,” and carried down a rubbish chute. Her parents dash in after her and are pushed in as well. Wonka explains the chute leads to the factory’s rubbish system and possibly the incinerator. The Oompa-Loompas sing a moral song blaming Veruca’s spoiling on her parents as the three disappear down the chute.

chapter.title: 29 The Other Children Go Home
chapter.summary_local: Mr. Wonka brings the elevator down to watch the departing Golden Ticket winners and their parents. Charlie, Grandpa Joe and Wonka observe Augustus Gloop climbing into a truck—now very thin after being squeezed in a pipe—Miss Violet appearing de-juiced but purple-faced, Veruca Salt and her parents covered in rubbish, and a hugely overstretched Mike Teavee. chapter.title: 30 Charlie's Chocolate Factory
chapter.summary_local: Mr Willy Wonka tells Charlie he will inherit the entire chocolate factory and explains he chose a child to learn his secrets. Wonka uses the great glass lift to go to Charlie’s tiny house and, by shooting through the roof, fetches Charlie’s parents and the bedridden grandparents (bringing the bed into the lift). Despite the elders’ terror and refusal, Wonka, Charlie and Grandpa Joe load the family into the lift and head back to the factory, with the household stunned but hopeful about food and their new life.
